actions-list.actionItem: The House adjourned. The next meeting is scheduled for 10:00 a.m. on May 23, 2023.
On motion to adjourn Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Newhouse moved that the House do now adjourn.
The House has concluded all anticipated legislative business and has proceeded to Special Order speeches.
The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.
The House observed a moment of silence in remembrance of former Representative Marion Berry of Arkansas.
On approving the Journal Agreed to by voice vote.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 400
actions-list.actionItem: 5 (Roll no. 229).

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 1156 — "To require the Secretary of the Treasury to conduct a study and report on the exposure of the United States to the financial sector of the People's Republic of China, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 402
actions-list.actionItem: 2 (Roll no. 228).

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 1076 — "To require the Comptroller General of the United States to carry out a study on the trafficking into the United States of synthetic drugs, and related illicit finance, and for other purposes."
The Chair announced that the unfinished business was the question on motions to suspend the rules which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of May 22.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for approximately 6:00 P.M. today.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion that the House suspend the rules and agree to the Senate amendment Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with 40 minutes of debate on the motion to suspend the rules and agree to the Senate amendment to H.R. 346.
Mr. Stauber moved that the House suspend the rules and agree to the Senate amendment.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 777.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bost moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. S. 777 — "To increase, effective as of December 1, 2023, the rates of compensation for veterans with service-connected disabilities and the rates of dependency and indemnity compensation for the survivors of certain disabled veterans, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1669.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bost moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 1669 — "To amend title 38, United States Code, to make permanent the high technology pilot program of the Department of Veterans Affairs, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 366.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bost moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 366 — "To amend title 38, United States Code, to treat certain individuals who served in Vietnam as a member of the armed forces of the Republic of Korea as a veteran of the Armed Forces of the United States for purposes of the provision of health care by the Department of Veterans Affairs."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1156.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Luetkemeyer moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 1156 — "To require the Secretary of the Treasury to conduct a study and report on the exposure of the United States to the financial sector of the People's Republic of China, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1076.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Luetkemeyer moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 1076 — "To require the Comptroller General of the United States to carry out a study on the trafficking into the United States of synthetic drugs, and related illicit finance, and for other purposes."
The Speaker announced that votes on suspensions, if ordered, will be postponed until a time to be announced.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of May 22.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is subject to the call of the Chair.

actions-list.header: Commission on Reform and Modernization of the Department of State
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to section 9803(d)(1)(C) and (E) of the James M. Inhofe National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2023 (Public Law 117-263), the Democratic Leader appointed the following member of the House to the Commission on Reform and Modernization of the Department of State: Mr. Quigley.

actions-list.header: Board of Visitors to the United States Naval Academy
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to 10 U.S.C. 8468(a), and the order of the House of January 9, 2023, the Speaker appointed the following member of the House to the Board of Visitors to the United States Naval Academy: Mr. Ruppersberger.
Pursuant to section 4003(e) of the 21st Century Cures Act (Public Law 114-255), and the order of the House of January 9, 2023, the Speaker appointed Dr. Jim Jirjis, Nashville, Tennessee.

actions-list.header: Board of Visitors to the United States Air Force Academy
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to 10 U.S.C. 9455(a), and the order of the House of January 9, 2023, the Speaker appointed the following member of the House to the Board of Visitors to the United States Air Force Academy: Mr. Davis of North Carolina.

actions-list.header: Board of Visitors to the United States Coast Guard Academy
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to 14 U.S.C. 1903(b), and the order of the House of January 9, 2023, the Speaker appointed the following member of the House to the Board of Visitors to the United States Coast Guard Academy: Mr. Courtney.

The House received a message from the Clerk. Pursuant to the permission granted in Clause 2(h) of Rule II of the Rules of the U.S. House of Representatives, the Clerk received the following message from the Secretary of the Senate on May 18, 2023, at 4:02 p.m.: That the Senate passed S.J. Res. 18.
The House proceeded with one minute speeches.
The Chair designated Mr. Allen to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.

The Chair announced that he had examined the Journal of the last day's proceedings and had approved it. Mr. Allen demanded that the question be put on agreeing to the Speaker's approval of the Journal and by voice vote, the Chair announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Allen objected to the voice vote based upon the absence of a quorum and the Chair postponed further proceedings on the question of agreeing to the Speaker's approval of the Journal until a time to be announced.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of May 22.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 2:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 2:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Barry Moore to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
